canonical_explanation.text: The p-block elements are those in which the last electron enters a p-orbital. They include Groups 13 to 18 (six groups). The general electronic configuration is ns² np¹⁻⁶. The NCERT Class 11 syllabus covers Group 13 (boron family: B, Al, Ga, In, Tl) and Group 14 (carbon family: C, Si, Ge, Sn, Pb). Group 13 elements have the general configuration ns² np¹. Boron is a non-metal, aluminium is a metal, and the metallic character increases down the group (Ga, In, Tl are metals). The oxidation states are +3 and +1. The stability of the +1 oxidation state increases down the group due to the inert pair effect (the ns² electrons become reluctant to participate in bonding as we go down). Tl⁺ is more stable than Tl³⁺. Boron shows anomalous behaviour due to its small size, high ionisation enthalpy, and absence of d-orbitals: it is a non-metal, forms covalent compounds, has a very high melting point, and forms borates and borohydrides rather than simple B³⁺ ions. Borax (Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O) is an important compound of boron. Its structure contains two tetrahedral and two trigonal planar boron atoms bridged by oxygen. In water, borax is hydrolysed to give an alkaline solution: Na₂B₄O₇ + 7H₂O → 2NaOH + 4H₃BO₃. On heating, borax first swells (loses water), then melts to a clear glassy bead of sodium metaborate and boric anhydride: Na₂B₄O₇ → 2NaBO₂ + B₂O₃. This bead test is used in qualitative analysis — coloured metal metaborates form when metal salts are heated with the borax bead (e.g., Co gives blue, Cr gives green, Cu gives blue in oxidising flame). Orthoboric acid (H₃BO₃) is a weak monobasic acid that does not donate a proton but accepts OH⁻ from water: H₃BO₃ + H₂O → [B(OH)₄]⁻ + H⁺. It has a layered structure with B(OH)₃ units held by hydrogen bonds. On heating: H₃BO₃ →(373K) HBO₂ (metaboric acid) →(red heat) B₂O₃ (boric anhydride). Diborane (B₂H₆) is the simplest boron hydride. It has a unique structure with four terminal B–H bonds (2-centre-2-electron, 2c-2e) and two bridging B–H–B bonds (3-centre-2-electron, 3c-2e banana bonds). It is prepared by: 2BF₃ + 6NaH → B₂H₆ + 6NaF, or from NaBH₄ + I₂. B₂H₆ burns in air: B₂H₆ + 3O₂ → B₂O₃ + 3H₂O (highly exothermic). It reacts with Lewis bases to form adducts: B₂H₆ + 2NMe₃ → 2BH₃·NMe₃. Aluminium is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust. It is extracted from bauxite (Al₂O₃·2H₂O) by the Bayer process (purification) followed by the Hall-Héroult process (electrolysis of Al₂O₃ dissolved in molten cryolite Na₃AlF₆ at ~1200 K). Al is a reactive metal but is rendered passive by a thin protective oxide layer (Al₂O₃). Al₂O₃ is amphoteric: Al₂O₃ + 6HCl → 2AlCl₃ + 3H₂O; Al₂O₃ + 2NaOH → 2NaAlO₂ + H₂O. AlCl₃ is a covalent compound that exists as a dimer Al₂Cl₆ with bridging chlorine atoms. Aluminium reacts with NaOH: 2Al + 2NaOH + 2H₂O → 2NaAlO₂ + 3H₂↑. Group 14 elements have the configuration ns² np². Carbon is a non-metal, silicon is a metalloid, germanium is a metalloid, tin and lead are metals. Oxidation states are +4 and +2; the stability of +2 increases down the group (inert pair effect — Pb²⁺ is more stable than Pb⁴⁺). Carbon shows catenation (ability to form long chains of C–C bonds) to the greatest extent among all elements due to the strength of the C–C bond (348 kJ/mol). Carbon exists as three allotropes: diamond (sp³, tetrahedral, hardest substance, insulator), graphite (sp², layered hexagonal, soft lubricant, conductor due to delocalised π-electrons), and fullerene (C₆₀, sp², spherical cage, 20 hexagons and 12 pentagons). Silicon exists as a network solid (sp³) with Si–Si bonds weaker than C–C. Oxides of carbon: CO is a neutral oxide (not acidic or basic), a powerful reducing agent, and a ligand in metal carbonyls. CO₂ is a linear molecule (O=C=O, sp hybridised carbon), an acidic oxide that dissolves in water to form carbonic acid (CO₂ + H₂O → H₂CO₃). Silicon dioxide (SiO₂, silica) is a covalent network solid with each Si bonded tetrahedrally to four oxygen atoms — unlike CO₂ which is a discrete molecule. This difference is because carbon forms strong pπ-pπ double bonds (C=O) while silicon cannot form effective pπ-pπ bonds due to its larger size, so it forms single Si–O–Si bonds instead. Silicones are synthetic organosilicon polymers with (R₂SiO)ₙ repeating units, with alternating Si–O–Si backbone. They are water repellent, heat resistant, and used as sealants, lubricants, and in medical implants. Zeolites are hydrated aluminosilicates with open framework structures containing channels and cavities occupied by water molecules and cations. General formula: Mₓ/ₙ[(AlO₂)ₓ(SiO₂)ᵧ]·mH₂O. They are used as molecular sieves (selective absorption based on pore size), shape-selective catalysts (e.g., ZSM-5 in petrochemistry), water softeners (ion exchange), and in detergent builders.
rules: p-block elements: Groups 13–18, general config ns² np¹⁻⁶; show variable oxidation states.
Inert pair effect: stability of lower oxidation state (+1 for Group 13, +2 for Group 14) increases down the group.
Borax bead test: Na₂B₄O₇ → 2NaBO₂ + B₂O₃; B₂O₃ dissolves metal oxides to form coloured metaborates.
H₃BO₃ is a weak monobasic Lewis acid — it accepts OH⁻ from water rather than donating H⁺.
Diborane (B₂H₆): 4 terminal 2c-2e B–H bonds + 2 bridging 3c-2e B–H–B (banana) bonds.
Al₂O₃ is amphoteric; AlCl₃ is covalent and exists as dimer Al₂Cl₆.
Carbon allotropes: diamond (sp³, insulator, hardest), graphite (sp², conductor, soft), fullerene (C₆₀, cage).
CO₂ is a discrete linear molecule; SiO₂ is a covalent network solid — difference due to pπ-pπ bonding ability of C vs Si.
Silicones: organosilicon polymers (R₂SiO)ₙ; water-repellent, heat-resistant, chemically inert.
Zeolites: aluminosilicates with cage structures; used as molecular sieves, shape-selective catalysts, and ion exchangers.
Carbon shows catenation most strongly due to strong C–C bond (348 kJ/mol); catenation decreases down Group 14.
Aluminium is extracted by Hall-Héroult process: electrolysis of Al₂O₃ in molten cryolite (Na₃AlF₆).

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of Group 13 elements is:
questions.explanation_correct: Group 13 elements (B, Al, Ga, In, Tl) have the general electronic configuration ns² np¹. They have three valence electrons — two in the s-orbital and one in the p-orbital. This gives them a common oxidation state of +3 (and +1 in heavier elements due to the inert pair effect).
questions.explanation_incorrect: ns² np² is the configuration of Group 14 (carbon family). ns¹ np² does not correspond to any standard group. ns² np³ is the configuration of Group 15 (nitrogen family). Group 13 has exactly one p-electron in the valence shell.

questions.question_text: The inert pair effect in Group 13 elements refers to:

options.text: The reluctance of ns² electrons to participate in bonding in heavier elements, stabilising the +1 oxidation state
The inability of boron to form any positive ions
The tendency of all Group 13 elements to show only +3 oxidation state
The pairing of d-electrons in transition metals

questions.explanation_correct: The inert pair effect describes the reluctance of the ns² electron pair to participate in bonding, particularly in heavier p-block elements. In Group 13, as we go from B to Tl, the +1 oxidation state becomes more stable (Tl⁺ is more stable than Tl³⁺). This is because the 6s² electrons in Tl are held tightly due to poor shielding by inner d and f electrons, making them less available for bonding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boron does not form B³⁺ ions due to very high ionisation energy, but this is not the inert pair effect. The inert pair effect specifically explains the increasing stability of the lower oxidation state (+1 for Group 13) as we go down the group. It has nothing to do with d-electron pairing in transition metals.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a non-metal in Group 13?
questions.explanation_correct: Boron (B) is the only non-metal in Group 13. It has very high ionisation enthalpy, small size, and high electronegativity compared to the other members. It forms covalent compounds and does not form B³⁺ ions. Aluminium, gallium, indium, and thallium are all metals with increasing metallic character down the group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aluminium is a light, highly reactive metal. Gallium is a metal (with unusually low melting point of 29.8°C). Thallium is a heavy, toxic metal. Only boron, at the top of Group 13, is classified as a non-metal (sometimes as a metalloid).

questions.question_text: Among Group 13 elements, the anomalous behaviour of boron is primarily due to:

options.text: Its large atomic size and low ionisation enthalpy
Its very small size, high ionisation enthalpy, high electronegativity, and absence of d-orbitals
The presence of completely filled d-orbitals
Its ability to form B³⁺ cation easily

questions.explanation_correct: Boron is anomalous in Group 13 because of its very small atomic size, high ionisation enthalpy (800.6 kJ/mol for IE₁), relatively high electronegativity (2.04), and the absence of d-orbitals in its valence shell (maximum coordination number 4). These factors make boron exclusively covalent, a non-metal, and very different from the metallic members Al, Ga, In, Tl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boron has a small (not large) atomic size and high (not low) ionisation enthalpy. It does not have d-orbitals (its electronic configuration is 1s² 2s² 2p¹). It cannot form B³⁺ cation easily because of the enormous energy required to remove three electrons from such a small atom. Its anomalous properties stem from small size and lack of d-orbitals.

questions.question_text: Thallium predominantly shows +1 oxidation state rather than +3 due to:

options.text: Inert pair effect — the 6s² electrons are reluctant to participate in bonding
Tl has very low ionisation enthalpy for its third electron
Tl³⁺ is too large to exist in crystal lattices

questions.explanation_correct: Thallium predominantly shows +1 oxidation state due to the inert pair effect. The 6s² electrons in Tl are held more tightly due to poor shielding by the intervening 4f and 5d electrons, increasing the effective nuclear charge felt by the 6s electrons. The energy required to use these s-electrons in bonding is not compensated by the lattice energy or bond energy of the resulting compound, so Tl⁺ (which retains the 6s² pair) is more stable than Tl³⁺.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tl has a large (not small) atomic size. The third ionisation enthalpy is actually high (not low), contributing to the reluctance to form Tl³⁺. Tl³⁺ being too large is not the reason — it is actually smaller than Tl⁺. The inert pair effect is the correct explanation.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about Group 13 elements:
(i) Metallic character increases from B to Tl.
(ii) The first ionisation enthalpy generally decreases from B to Tl.
(iii) Boron forms exclusively ionic compounds.
Which of the above is/are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (i) is correct: metallic character increases from B (non-metal) to Al, Ga, In, Tl (metals). Statement (ii) is generally correct: IE₁ decreases from B (800.6) to Al (577.5) to Ga (578.8) to In (558.3) to Tl (589.4) kJ/mol — the general trend is decreasing, though there are small irregularities due to poor shielding by d/f electrons. Statement (iii) is incorrect: boron forms exclusively covalent compounds, not ionic ones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (iii) is wrong. Boron forms covalent (not ionic) compounds because of its very small size, high ionisation enthalpy, and high charge density that would be needed for B³⁺. It never forms simple B³⁺ ions. Statements (i) and (ii) are both correct.

questions.question_text: The atomic radius of Ga (135 pm) is slightly less than that of Al (143 pm) despite Ga being below Al in Group 13. This is because:

options.text: Ga has fewer electron shells than Al
Poor shielding by the 3d electrons in Ga increases the effective nuclear charge on valence electrons
Ga has a higher principal quantum number which contracts the atom
Al has d-electrons that expand its atomic radius

questions.explanation_correct: Gallium (Z=31) has the electronic configuration [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p¹. The 3d electrons provide poor shielding of the nuclear charge (d-orbitals have diffuse shapes with poor penetration). This means the outer 4s and 4p electrons experience a higher effective nuclear charge than expected, pulling them closer to the nucleus and reducing the atomic radius. This makes Ga slightly smaller than Al despite being in the next period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ga has more electron shells than Al (Ga: 4 shells, Al: 3 shells), not fewer. Higher principal quantum number normally increases atomic radius, but here the poor d-electron shielding counteracts this. Al does not have d-electrons. The key factor is the poor shielding by the filled 3d subshell in Ga.

questions.question_text: Borax has the chemical formula:
questions.explanation_correct: Borax is sodium tetraborate decahydrate with the formula Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O. It is a naturally occurring mineral found in dried lake beds. Its crystal structure contains tetrahedral [B(OH)₄]⁻ units and trigonal planar B(OH)₃ units linked by shared oxygen atoms. It is an important source of boron and is used in making glass, enamel, pottery glazes, and as a flux in metallurgy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaBO₂ is sodium metaborate. Na₃BO₃ is not a standard boron compound. H₃BO₃ is boric acid (orthoboric acid), which is a different compound entirely. Borax specifically refers to the decahydrate of sodium tetraborate.

questions.question_text: When borax is dissolved in water, the solution is:
questions.explanation_correct: Borax solution is alkaline because borax undergoes hydrolysis in water: Na₂B₄O₇ + 7H₂O → 2NaOH + 4H₃BO₃. Since NaOH is a strong base and H₃BO₃ is a very weak acid, the resulting solution is basic (pH > 7). This alkalinity makes borax useful as a cleaning agent and a water softener.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Borax solution is not acidic (H₃BO₃ produced is a weak acid, but NaOH is a strong base, so the solution is net alkaline). It is not neutral because hydrolysis produces unequal strength acid and base. It is not an oxidising agent. The alkaline nature of borax solution is a fundamental property.

questions.question_text: Orthoboric acid (H₃BO₃) is a weak acid that acts as a:

options.text: Brønsted acid — donates H⁺ directly to water
Lewis acid — accepts OH⁻ from water to form [B(OH)₄]⁻
Strong diprotic acid releasing two H⁺ ions
Amphoteric substance acting as both acid and base

questions.explanation_correct: H₃BO₃ does not donate a proton directly. Instead, it acts as a Lewis acid by accepting a hydroxide ion from water: H₃BO₃ + H₂O ⇌ [B(OH)₄]⁻ + H⁺. The boron atom, being electron-deficient (has only 6 electrons in its valence shell), accepts the OH⁻ to complete its octet, forming the tetrahedral [B(OH)₄]⁻ ion. This makes H₃BO₃ a monobasic Lewis acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₃BO₃ is not a Brønsted acid (it does not donate H⁺ directly). It is not diprotic or triprotic — despite having three OH groups, it is monobasic. It is not amphoteric in the traditional sense. Its acidity arises from its Lewis acid behaviour (accepting OH⁻ from water).

questions.question_text: In the borax bead test, when a cobalt salt is heated with borax bead in an oxidising flame, the bead colour is:
questions.explanation_correct: When borax is heated, it forms a glassy bead of NaBO₂ + B₂O₃. When a cobalt salt is heated with this bead in an oxidising flame, cobalt metaborate [Co(BO₂)₂] is formed, which gives a characteristic deep blue colour. This borax bead test is used in qualitative analysis to identify certain metal ions: Co = blue, Cr = green, Cu = blue (oxidising)/red (reducing), Mn = violet, Fe = yellow/brown, Ni = brown.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green bead is characteristic of chromium. Brown indicates nickel or iron. The borax bead with cobalt gives a distinctive deep blue colour in both oxidising and reducing flames, making it one of the most reliable results in the borax bead test.

questions.question_text: Diborane (B₂H₆) has a unique bonding structure. The bridging B–H–B bonds are described as:

options.text: Ionic bonds between B³⁺ and H⁻
Coordinate (dative) bonds from H to B

questions.explanation_correct: The two bridging B–H–B bonds in diborane are 3-centre-2-electron (3c-2e) bonds, also called banana bonds or tau bonds. In each bridging bond, one pair of electrons is shared among three atoms (two B and one H). This unusual bonding arises because B₂H₆ is electron-deficient — it has only 12 valence electrons (6 from 2B + 6 from 6H), insufficient for 8 normal bonds, so it uses the 3c-2e bonding to maximise bonding with available electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The terminal B–H bonds are normal 2c-2e bonds, but the bridging bonds are not. The bonding is not ionic. The bridging H atoms do not have lone pairs to form coordinate bonds. The 3c-2e banana bond is the correct description of the bridging B–H–B bonds.

questions.question_text: Diborane can be prepared by the reaction:
questions.explanation_correct: Diborane is prepared by treating boron trifluoride (BF₃) with sodium hydride (NaH) in diglyme: 2BF₃ + 6NaH → B₂H₆ + 6NaF. This is a standard laboratory method. Industrially, it can also be prepared by reaction of BF₃ etherate with LiAlH₄ or NaBH₄. Another method uses NaBH₄ + I₂ → B₂H₆ + NaI + H₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: BCl₃ does not react with H₂ directly to form B₂H₆ under normal conditions. B₂O₃ + H₂O gives H₃BO₃, not B₂H₆. Elemental boron reacting with Cl₂ gives BCl₃, not a hydride. The correct preparation involves treating a boron halide with a metal hydride (NaH or LiAlH₄).

questions.question_text: When H₃BO₃ (boric acid) is heated, the sequence of products formed is:

options.text: H₃BO₃ →(373K) HBO₂ (metaboric acid) →(red heat) B₂O₃ (boric anhydride)

questions.explanation_correct: On heating, boric acid undergoes stepwise dehydration: H₃BO₃ →(373 K) HBO₂ (metaboric acid) + H₂O; HBO₂ →(red heat) B₂O₃ (boric anhydride or boron trioxide) + H₂O. The first step removes one molecule of water per boric acid unit, forming metaboric acid. Further strong heating drives off the remaining water to form the glassy B₂O₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The dehydration is stepwise, not a single step. H₂B₄O₇ and BH₃ are not products of heating boric acid. NaBO₂ and Na₂B₄O₇ are sodium salts, not thermal decomposition products. The correct sequence is H₃BO₃ → HBO₂ → B₂O₃.

questions.question_text: In the structure of diborane (B₂H₆), how many terminal and bridging hydrogen atoms are present?
questions.explanation_correct: B₂H₆ has 4 terminal hydrogen atoms (2 on each boron) and 2 bridging hydrogen atoms. Each boron atom is bonded to 2 terminal H atoms by normal 2c-2e bonds and shares 2 bridging H atoms with the other boron through 3c-2e bonds. The terminal B–H bond length (119 pm) is shorter than the bridging B–H bond length (131 pm) because the bridging bond involves electron sharing among three centres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If all 6 H atoms were terminal, there would not be enough electrons for bonding (B₂H₆ has only 12 valence electrons, 8 are needed for 4 terminal B–H bonds, leaving only 4 electrons for 2 bridging bonds). The structure with 4 terminal + 2 bridging hydrogens correctly accounts for the electron count: 4×2 + 2×2 = 12 electrons.

questions.question_text: H₃BO₃ has a layered structure held together by:

options.text: Hydrogen bonds between B(OH)₃ units in a planar layer
Ionic bonds between B³⁺ and OH⁻ ions

questions.explanation_correct: H₃BO₃ (boric acid) has a layered crystal structure. Within each layer, planar trigonal B(OH)₃ molecules are linked by extensive O–H···O hydrogen bonds, forming a two-dimensional sheet. The layers are held together by weak van der Waals forces, which is why boric acid feels soapy/slippery (similar to graphite's layered structure). This layered structure with easy cleavage between layers gives H₃BO₃ its characteristic flaky appearance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are no covalent bonds between the layers — only weak van der Waals forces. H₃BO₃ is a molecular compound, not ionic (no B³⁺ or OH⁻ ions). There are no metallic bonds. The key structural feature is the hydrogen-bonded layers of B(OH)₃ units.

questions.question_text: Aluminium is extracted from its ore bauxite by the Hall-Héroult process, which involves:

options.text: Reduction of Al₂O₃ with carbon at high temperature
Electrolysis of purified Al₂O₃ dissolved in molten cryolite (Na₃AlF₆)
Heating bauxite with HCl to form AlCl₃, then electrolysis
Reduction of Al₂O₃ with hydrogen gas

questions.explanation_correct: In the Hall-Héroult process, purified alumina (Al₂O₃), obtained from bauxite by the Bayer process, is dissolved in molten cryolite (Na₃AlF₆) at about 1200 K (which lowers the melting point from 2345 K for pure Al₂O₃ to ~1200 K). Electrolysis is carried out using carbon electrodes. Molten aluminium collects at the carbon cathode (Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ → Al), and oxygen is liberated at the carbon anode (which burns to CO₂).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon reduction of Al₂O₃ is not feasible because aluminium has a very high affinity for oxygen (very negative ΔfG° for Al₂O₃). Al₂O₃ is too stable to be reduced by C or H₂ under practical conditions. The AlCl₃ electrolysis route is not industrially viable. Only electrolysis of Al₂O₃ in molten cryolite (Hall-Héroult process) is used commercially.

questions.question_text: Aluminium oxide (Al₂O₃) is amphoteric. Which pair of reactions demonstrates this?

options.text: Al₂O₃ + H₂O → Al(OH)₃ (only basic); Al₂O₃ + HCl → no reaction
Al₂O₃ + NaOH → no reaction; Al₂O₃ + HNO₃ → Al(NO₃)₃
Al₂O₃ acts only as a base, dissolving in acids but not in alkalis

questions.explanation_correct: Al₂O₃ is amphoteric — it reacts with both acids and bases. With acid (acting as a base): Al₂O₃ + 6HCl → 2AlCl₃ + 3H₂O. With alkali (acting as an acid): Al₂O₃ + 2NaOH → 2NaAlO₂ (sodium aluminate) + H₂O. This dual reactivity is the hallmark of amphoteric oxides. Other amphoteric oxides include ZnO, PbO, and BeO.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Al₂O₃ definitely reacts with both acids and bases — it is not exclusively basic or exclusively acidic. Options B, C, and D incorrectly state that Al₂O₃ does not react with one of these. The ability to dissolve in both acids and alkalis defines its amphoteric character.

questions.question_text: AlCl₃ exists as a dimer Al₂Cl₆ because:

options.text: Al³⁺ is very large and needs more chloride ions
Aluminium in AlCl₃ is electron-deficient (has only 6 electrons) and achieves an octet by forming coordinate bonds with chlorine lone pairs
Chlorine atoms share electrons with each other
AlCl₃ is an ionic compound that forms ion pairs

questions.explanation_correct: In monomeric AlCl₃, aluminium has only 6 electrons in its valence shell (3 from Al + 3 shared with Cl), making it electron-deficient. To achieve an octet, two AlCl₃ units dimerise to form Al₂Cl₆, where two chlorine atoms bridge the two aluminium atoms by donating lone pairs (coordinate bonds: Cl→Al). Each Al then achieves tetrahedral coordination with 8 electrons in its valence shell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Al³⁺ is actually small, not large. The Cl atoms do not share electrons with each other in the dimer. AlCl₃ is predominantly covalent, not ionic. The driving force for dimerisation is the electron deficiency of Al, which is resolved by bridging Cl atoms forming coordinate bonds.

questions.question_text: Aluminium dissolves in NaOH solution with the evolution of hydrogen gas. The balanced equation is:
questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium reacts with aqueous NaOH: 2Al + 2NaOH + 2H₂O → 2NaAlO₂ + 3H₂↑. Aluminium dissolves in alkali because its oxide is amphoteric. The reaction produces sodium aluminate (NaAlO₂) and hydrogen gas. This reaction demonstrates aluminium's ability to act as a reducing agent and the amphoteric nature of Al₂O₃/Al(OH)₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is unbalanced. Option C is incorrect — free sodium metal is not produced by dissolving Al in NaOH solution. Option D has incorrect stoichiometry and formula. The correctly balanced equation requires 2 moles each of Al, NaOH, and H₂O to produce 2 moles of NaAlO₂ and 3 moles of H₂.

questions.question_text: Aluminium does not react with water under normal conditions because:

options.text: Aluminium is a noble metal with very low reactivity
A thin, tough, transparent layer of Al₂O₃ on its surface protects it from further reaction
Water cannot dissolve aluminium at any temperature
Aluminium and water are in the same oxidation state

questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium is actually quite reactive (E° = −1.66 V), but it does not react with water under normal conditions because it forms a very thin (~4 nm), tough, adherent layer of aluminium oxide (Al₂O₃) on its surface when exposed to air. This oxide layer is non-porous, transparent, and very resistant, effectively passivating the metal and preventing water or oxygen from reaching the underlying aluminium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aluminium is NOT a noble metal — it is highly reactive thermodynamically (used in thermite reactions). It is not that water cannot dissolve it — if the oxide layer is removed (e.g., by amalgamation with Hg), Al reacts vigorously with water. Oxidation state argument is irrelevant. The protective oxide film is the correct reason.

questions.question_text: The role of cryolite (Na₃AlF₆) in the Hall-Héroult process is to:

options.text: Lower the melting point of Al₂O₃ and increase the electrical conductivity of the melt
Act as a reducing agent for Al₂O₃
Prevent oxidation of aluminium produced at the cathode

questions.explanation_correct: Pure Al₂O₃ has a very high melting point (2345 K), making direct electrolysis impractical and energy-intensive. Cryolite (Na₃AlF₆) acts as a solvent that dissolves Al₂O₃ and lowers the working temperature to about 1200 K. It also increases the electrical conductivity of the melt, allowing efficient electrolysis. A small amount of CaF₂ (fluorspar) is added to further lower the melting point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cryolite does not provide sodium for the reaction — Na is not a product. It is not a reducing agent (electrolysis provides the electrons for reduction). It does not specifically prevent oxidation of Al at the cathode. Its role is purely physical — reducing the operating temperature and improving conductivity.

questions.question_text: In the thermite process, aluminium powder reacts with iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃) to produce:

options.text: Al₂O₃ + Fe (molten iron), with intense heat (~2500°C)

questions.explanation_correct: The thermite reaction is: 2Al + Fe₂O₃ → Al₂O₃ + 2Fe + huge amount of heat. This highly exothermic reaction (ΔH ≈ −850 kJ/mol) produces temperatures around 2500°C, yielding molten iron. It is used for welding iron rails (railway tracks), in incendiary devices, and for producing metals from their oxides when carbon reduction is not feasible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No chlorine is involved (AlCl₃ is not formed). The products are not a mixed oxide or FeO + O₂. The thermite reaction is a simple displacement: Al reduces Fe₂O₃ to metallic iron while being oxidised to Al₂O₃. The enormous heat produced is the defining feature.

questions.question_text: In the Bayer process for purification of bauxite, Al₂O₃ is selectively dissolved using:

options.text: Concentrated NaOH solution at ~470 K under pressure

questions.explanation_correct: In the Bayer process, crushed bauxite (Al₂O₃·2H₂O with impurities of Fe₂O₃ and SiO₂) is digested with concentrated NaOH solution (45%) at about 470 K under pressure. The amphoteric Al₂O₃ dissolves as sodium aluminate: Al₂O₃ + 2NaOH → 2NaAlO₂ + H₂O. The impurities (Fe₂O₃ is basic, insoluble in NaOH) are filtered off as 'red mud'. The filtrate is then diluted and seeded with Al(OH)₃ crystals to precipitate pure Al(OH)₃, which is calcined to pure Al₂O₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCl and H₂SO₄ would dissolve both Al₂O₃ and Fe₂O₃ impurities without selectivity. Molten NaCl is used in electrolysis, not purification. NaOH selectively dissolves only Al₂O₃ (amphoteric) while leaving Fe₂O₃ (basic, insoluble in NaOH) behind, enabling purification.

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of Group 14 elements is:
questions.explanation_correct: Group 14 elements (C, Si, Ge, Sn, Pb) have the general electronic configuration ns² np², with four valence electrons. They can show oxidation states of +4 (using all four electrons) and +2 (using only the two p-electrons, leaving the ns² inert pair). The +4 state is predominant for C and Si, while the +2 state becomes more stable for Sn and Pb (inert pair effect).
questions.explanation_incorrect: ns² np¹ is Group 13. ns² np³ is Group 15 (nitrogen family). ns² np⁴ is Group 16 (oxygen family). Group 14 specifically has two s and two p valence electrons.

questions.question_text: Carbon shows the property of catenation to the greatest extent because:

options.text: Carbon has a very large atomic radius
The C–C bond is very strong (348 kJ/mol) due to the small size of carbon and effective orbital overlap
Carbon has vacant d-orbitals for bonding
Carbon forms only ionic bonds with itself

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon shows maximum catenation (ability to form long chains of self-linked atoms) because the C–C single bond is very strong (348 kJ/mol). This strength arises from the small atomic size of carbon, which allows very effective overlap of its sp³ hybrid orbitals. As we go down Group 14, the M–M bond strength decreases (Si–Si: 226 kJ/mol, Ge–Ge: 188 kJ/mol), and catenation ability diminishes accordingly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon has a small (not large) atomic radius, which is exactly why its bonds are strong. Carbon does NOT have d-orbitals in its valence shell (2s² 2p²). Carbon forms covalent (not ionic) bonds. The key factor is the exceptional strength of the C–C bond due to small size and effective orbital overlap.

questions.question_text: Diamond is an allotrope of carbon in which each carbon atom is:

options.text: sp² hybridised, bonded to three other carbon atoms in a planar structure
sp³ hybridised, bonded tetrahedrally to four other carbon atoms in a 3D network
sp hybridised, bonded linearly to two other carbon atoms

questions.explanation_correct: In diamond, each carbon atom is sp³ hybridised and bonded tetrahedrally to four other carbon atoms by strong covalent bonds, forming a giant three-dimensional network. The C–C bond length is 154 pm. This extensive 3D network of strong covalent bonds makes diamond the hardest known natural substance, with a very high melting point (~4000 K). Diamond is an electrical insulator because all electrons are localised in C–C bonds (no free electrons or delocalised π-electrons).
questions.explanation_incorrect: sp² hybridisation with planar structure describes graphite, not diamond. sp hybridisation with linear structure describes carbyne. Diamond has no metallic bonding — it is purely covalent. The sp³ tetrahedral arrangement is the defining structural feature of diamond.

questions.question_text: Graphite is a good conductor of electricity because:

options.text: Each carbon atom in graphite is sp² hybridised, and the unhybridised p-electrons form a delocalised π-electron cloud between layers
It has strong van der Waals forces between layers
It has ionic bonds between the carbon layers

questions.explanation_correct: In graphite, each carbon atom is sp² hybridised and bonded to three other carbon atoms in flat hexagonal layers. The fourth electron (in the unhybridised 2p orbital perpendicular to the plane) participates in extended delocalised π-bonding across the entire layer. These delocalised electrons are mobile and can carry electrical current, making graphite a good conductor of electricity parallel to the layers (but a poor conductor perpendicular to them).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Graphite contains no free metal ions or ionic bonds. The van der Waals forces between layers are weak (which is why graphite is soft and slippery), but they do not contribute to electrical conductivity. The conductivity comes exclusively from the delocalised π-electrons within each layer.

questions.question_text: Fullerene (C₆₀) has the shape of a:

options.text: Spherical cage (truncated icosahedron) with 20 hexagons and 12 pentagons

questions.explanation_correct: Fullerene C₆₀ (buckminsterfullerene) has a spherical cage structure resembling a football (soccer ball). It is a truncated icosahedron with 20 hexagonal faces and 12 pentagonal faces, containing 60 carbon atoms at the vertices. Each carbon is sp² hybridised and bonded to three other carbons. It was discovered in 1985 by Kroto, Curl, and Smalley (Nobel Prize 1996). The pentagons create the curvature needed to close the cage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flat hexagonal sheets describe graphite. Tetrahedral structures describe diamond. Linear chains describe carbynes. Fullerene's unique feature is its closed cage/sphere structure with both hexagons and pentagons (like a soccer ball).

questions.question_text: Silicon exists as a covalent network solid rather than forming discrete molecules like carbon (e.g., CO₂ vs SiO₂). This difference is because:

options.text: Silicon is more electronegative than carbon
Silicon cannot form effective pπ-pπ double bonds due to its larger atomic size, so it forms single bonds in extended networks
Silicon has a smaller atomic radius than carbon
Silicon is a metal and forms metallic bonds

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon is small enough to form effective pπ-pπ double bonds (as in CO₂: O=C=O), allowing discrete molecules. Silicon is much larger, so its 3p orbitals overlap poorly with 2p orbitals of oxygen, making Si=O double bonds very weak. Instead, silicon forms four strong single bonds (Si–O) in a tetrahedral network, resulting in polymeric/network structures like SiO₂ (quartz). This explains why CO₂ is a gas but SiO₂ is a high-melting solid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicon is less electronegative than carbon (Si: 1.8, C: 2.5), not more. Silicon has a larger (not smaller) atomic radius than carbon. Silicon is a metalloid, not a metal. The key difference is the inability of silicon to form strong pπ-pπ multiple bonds due to its larger size and more diffuse orbitals.

questions.question_text: Among Group 14 elements, the stability of the +2 oxidation state increases down the group. Which element predominantly shows the +2 state?
questions.explanation_correct: Lead (Pb) predominantly shows the +2 oxidation state due to the inert pair effect. The 6s² electrons in Pb are held tightly and are reluctant to participate in bonding because of poor shielding by the inner 4f and 5d electrons. Pb²⁺ compounds (PbO, PbCl₂, PbSO₄) are much more stable than Pb⁴⁺ compounds (PbO₂ is a strong oxidising agent, indicating instability of Pb⁴⁺). In contrast, C and Si predominantly show +4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon and silicon predominantly show +4 oxidation state. Germanium shows both +2 and +4 with +4 being more common. Lead is the element where the inert pair effect is most pronounced in Group 14, making Pb²⁺ the dominant oxidation state.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about carbon allotropes is INCORRECT?

options.text: Diamond is the hardest known natural substance with sp³ hybridised carbon
Graphite is a good conductor of electricity due to delocalised π-electrons
Diamond is a good conductor of electricity because of its rigid structure
Fullerene C₆₀ has a cage-like structure with sp² hybridised carbon atoms

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that diamond is a good conductor of electricity is INCORRECT. Diamond is actually one of the best electrical insulators known. All four valence electrons of each carbon are used in forming strong C–C sigma bonds (sp³), leaving no free or delocalised electrons for electrical conduction. Graphite, on the other hand, is a good conductor because of its delocalised π-electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct. Diamond is indeed the hardest natural substance (sp³ network). Graphite conducts electricity due to delocalised π-electrons. C₆₀ does have a cage structure with sp² carbon. Only option C is wrong — diamond is an insulator, not a conductor.

questions.question_text: The catenation ability of elements in Group 14 follows the order:
questions.explanation_correct: Catenation ability decreases dramatically down Group 14: C >> Si > Ge > Sn >> Pb. This directly correlates with the M–M bond energy: C–C (348 kJ/mol) >> Si–Si (226) > Ge–Ge (188) > Sn–Sn (151) >> Pb–Pb (~100 kJ/mol). Carbon's small size leads to excellent orbital overlap and very strong C–C bonds, enabling long stable chains (organic chemistry). Heavier elements have weaker self-linkage bonds and show minimal catenation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Catenation decreases (not increases) down the group. All elements do not have equal catenation ability. Carbon is by far the best at catenation — it is the basis of all organic molecules. Silicon shows limited catenation (silanes up to Si₆H₁₄), and heavier elements show even less.

questions.question_text: Carbon monoxide (CO) is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: CO is a neutral oxide — it does not react with water, acids, or bases under normal conditions to form salts. It is neither acidic nor basic. However, CO is a powerful reducing agent (used in blast furnaces: Fe₂O₃ + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO₂) and forms coordination compounds with transition metals (metal carbonyls like Ni(CO)₄). Other neutral oxides include N₂O, NO, and H₂O (approximately).
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO₂ is the acidic oxide of carbon (CO₂ + H₂O → H₂CO₃), not CO. CO does not exhibit basic or amphoteric behaviour either. CO is specifically classified as a neutral oxide, which is somewhat unusual for a non-metal oxide.

questions.question_text: CO₂ has a linear molecular geometry because:

options.text: Carbon is sp³ hybridised with tetrahedral geometry
Carbon is sp hybridised with two C=O double bonds at 180°
Carbon is sp² hybridised with one lone pair
Oxygen atoms repel each other to become linear

questions.explanation_correct: In CO₂, the central carbon atom is sp hybridised, forming two sigma bonds with two oxygen atoms. Each C=O also has a π-bond (from unhybridised p-orbitals). The two sp hybrid orbitals point in opposite directions (180° apart), giving CO₂ its linear geometry: O=C=O. The molecule has no lone pairs on carbon, no dipole moment (the two C=O dipoles cancel), and is non-polar overall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sp³ hybridisation would give tetrahedral geometry (as in CH₄). sp² hybridisation with a lone pair would give a bent molecule. The linear geometry is specifically due to sp hybridisation of carbon. The linearity is not simply due to repulsion between O atoms — it is a consequence of the hybridisation and bonding.

questions.question_text: Silicon dioxide (SiO₂) has a very high melting point (1713°C) because it is:

options.text: A discrete molecular compound like CO₂
An ionic compound with strong electrostatic forces
A three-dimensional covalent network solid with strong Si–O bonds
A metallic solid with free electrons

questions.explanation_correct: SiO₂ (silica, quartz) is a three-dimensional covalent network solid where each silicon atom is tetrahedrally bonded to four oxygen atoms, and each oxygen bridges two silicon atoms. This creates a continuous network of strong Si–O covalent bonds (bond energy ~466 kJ/mol) extending throughout the crystal. Breaking this network requires enormous energy, resulting in a very high melting point. Unlike CO₂ (a discrete molecule, gas at room temperature), SiO₂ forms a macromolecular solid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SiO₂ is fundamentally different from CO₂ — it is not a discrete molecule. It is not ionic (the Si–O bonds are polar covalent). It is not metallic. The 3D covalent network of Si–O–Si linkages is the reason for its very high melting point and extreme hardness.

questions.question_text: Silicones are organosilicon polymers with the general formula (R₂SiO)ₙ. They are used in many applications because they are:

options.text: Strong acids that react with metals

questions.explanation_correct: Silicones are synthetic polymers with a backbone of alternating Si and O atoms, with organic groups (usually methyl, CH₃) attached to Si. They are water-repellent (hydrophobic due to organic groups), heat-resistant (Si–O bonds are strong and thermally stable), electrically insulating, and chemically inert. They are used as sealants, lubricants, in medical implants, water-proofing agents, hydraulic fluids, and as non-stick coatings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicones are electrical insulators, not conductors. They are not acids and do not react with metals under normal conditions. They are not biodegradable (a disadvantage) and are water-repellent (not water-soluble). Their key properties — water repellency, thermal stability, and chemical inertness — make them industrially valuable.

questions.question_text: Zeolites are used as molecular sieves because they:

options.text: Are soluble in water and dissolve impurities
Have an open framework structure with channels and cavities of specific sizes that selectively absorb molecules
Contain free metal atoms that react with molecules of specific sizes
Are magnetic and attract specific molecules

questions.explanation_correct: Zeolites are hydrated aluminosilicates with an open three-dimensional framework structure containing channels, cavities, and pores of precise molecular dimensions. They can selectively absorb or exclude molecules based on their size and shape — molecules that fit through the pore openings are absorbed, while larger molecules are excluded. This size-selective absorption makes them excellent molecular sieves. ZSM-5, for example, has pore sizes of ~5.5 Å.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zeolites are insoluble in water (they are solid aluminosilicate frameworks). They do not contain free metal atoms. They are not magnetic. Their molecular sieving ability is purely a physical/structural property based on the uniform pore sizes in their crystal structure.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a correct statement about CO₂ and SiO₂?

options.text: Both are discrete molecular compounds existing as gases at room temperature
CO₂ is a gas (discrete molecule with C=O double bonds) while SiO₂ is a high-melting solid (3D network with Si–O single bonds)
Both have identical structures because C and Si are in the same group
SiO₂ is a gas and CO₂ is a solid at room temperature

questions.explanation_correct: CO₂ is a discrete linear molecule (O=C=O) held together by weak van der Waals forces between molecules — it is a gas at room temperature (sublimes at −78.5°C). SiO₂ is a 3D covalent network solid with each Si bonded to four O atoms through single bonds (Si–O–Si bridges) — it is a solid with melting point 1713°C. The difference arises because C forms strong pπ-pπ double bonds (C=O) while Si, being larger, cannot, so it forms single bonds in an extended network.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO₂ and SiO₂ do NOT have identical structures despite being in the same group. SiO₂ is a solid (not a gas) and CO₂ is a gas (not a solid) at room temperature. Their structures are fundamentally different due to the difference in bonding ability of C vs Si.

questions.question_text: Zeolites are used as shape-selective catalysts. In the petrochemical industry, ZSM-5 zeolite is used for:

options.text: Manufacturing ammonia from N₂ and H₂

questions.explanation_correct: ZSM-5 (Zeolite Socony Mobil-5) is a shape-selective catalyst used in the petrochemical industry for the conversion of methanol to gasoline (MTG process — Methanol To Gasoline). The uniform pore structure of ZSM-5 controls which reactant molecules can enter, which products can form inside the pores, and which products can exit, leading to selective formation of gasoline-range hydrocarbons. It is also used for xylene isomerisation and catalytic cracking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ammonia synthesis (Haber process) uses iron catalyst. Sulphuric acid (Contact process) uses V₂O₅ catalyst. Gold refining uses cyanide leaching. ZSM-5 is specifically known for converting methanol to gasoline and for shape-selective catalysis in hydrocarbon processing.

questions.question_text: Silicones are prepared from organosilicon compounds called alkyl-substituted chlorosilanes (e.g., R₂SiCl₂). The process involves:

options.text: Direct polymerisation of SiO₂ with alkyl halides
Hydrolysis of R₂SiCl₂ to form R₂Si(OH)₂, followed by condensation polymerisation to form (R₂SiO)ₙ
Reduction of SiO₂ with carbon and organic halides
Heating silica gel with methanol at high pressure

questions.explanation_correct: Silicones are prepared by first hydrolysing dialkyl/diaryl chlorosilanes: R₂SiCl₂ + 2H₂O → R₂Si(OH)₂ + 2HCl. The silanols (R₂Si(OH)₂) then undergo condensation polymerisation, where Si–OH groups react with each other to form Si–O–Si linkages with elimination of water: nR₂Si(OH)₂ → (R₂SiO)ₙ + nH₂O. The resulting polymer has an alternating Si–O backbone with organic groups on each silicon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SiO₂ does not directly polymerise with alkyl halides. Reducing SiO₂ with carbon gives elemental Si, not silicones. Heating silica gel with methanol does not produce silicones. The correct route involves hydrolysis of chlorosilanes followed by condensation polymerisation.

questions.question_text: Among Group 13 elements, which element has an unusually low melting point of 29.8°C?
questions.explanation_correct: Gallium (Ga) has an unusually low melting point of 29.8°C (303 K) — it can melt in your hand! This is anomalous for a metal and is due to its unusual crystal structure (orthorhombic with Ga₂ dimers). Despite the low melting point, gallium has a very high boiling point (2477°C), giving it one of the largest liquid ranges of any element. It is used in high-temperature thermometers and semiconductors (GaAs).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boron has a very high melting point (2349°C) — it is a non-metal/metalloid. Aluminium melts at 660°C. Thallium melts at 304°C. Gallium's melting point of 29.8°C is uniquely low, and it is one of few metals that are liquid near room temperature (along with Hg and Cs).

questions.question_text: Diborane (B₂H₆) reacts with excess ammonia (NH₃) at high temperature to form:

options.text: Boron nitride (BN), an inorganic analogue of graphite
Borazine (B₃N₃H₆), an inorganic analogue of benzene

questions.explanation_correct: At high temperatures, B₂H₆ reacts with excess NH₃ to form boron nitride (BN): B₂H₆ + 2NH₃ →(high temp) 2BN + 6H₂. BN is an inorganic analogue of graphite (they are isoelectronic: B–N is isoelectronic with C–C). Hexagonal BN has a layered structure like graphite but is white and an electrical insulator (because the electrons are localised in the polar B–N bonds). Cubic BN (borazon) is almost as hard as diamond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Borazine (B₃N₃H₆, inorganic benzene) forms when B₂H₆ and NH₃ react in equimolar ratio at moderate temperatures: 3B₂H₆ + 6NH₃ → 2B₃N₃H₆ + 12H₂. At high temperature with excess NH₃, the product is BN, not borazine. N₂ and H₂O are not the products. NH₄BO₂ is not formed under these conditions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements in Group 14 is considered a metalloid?
questions.explanation_correct: Silicon and germanium are classified as metalloids (semimetals) in Group 14. They have intermediate properties between metals and non-metals. Both are semiconductors — their electrical conductivity is between that of metals and insulators. Carbon is a non-metal, while tin and lead are metals. The metallic character increases down Group 14: C (non-metal) → Si, Ge (metalloids) → Sn, Pb (metals).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon is a non-metal (not a metalloid). Tin and lead are metals (not metalloids). Silicon and germanium occupy the intermediate position in the group and have semiconductor properties, making them metalloids. This classification is consistent with their position on the metal-non-metal boundary in the periodic table.

questions.question_text: CO₂ dissolves in water to form:

options.text: Carbonic acid (H₂CO₃), making the solution weakly acidic

questions.explanation_correct: CO₂ dissolves in water to form carbonic acid: CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃. Carbonic acid is a weak diprotic acid that partially dissociates: H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻ (Ka₁ ≈ 4.3 × 10⁻⁷); HCO₃⁻ ⇌ H⁺ + CO₃²⁻ (Ka₂ ≈ 4.7 × 10⁻¹¹). This is why CO₂ is classified as an acidic oxide and why carbonated water (soda water) is slightly acidic (pH ~4).
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO₂ does not decompose to CO in water. It does not form methanol or formic acid by simply dissolving in water (those would require catalytic reduction). The correct product is carbonic acid, which makes the solution weakly acidic.

questions.question_text: Aluminium is used in the thermite welding of iron rails and in the extraction of metals like chromium and manganese from their oxides because:

options.text: Aluminium has a very low melting point
Aluminium has a very high affinity for oxygen and acts as a powerful reducing agent
Aluminium forms Al₂O₃ which is easily decomposed

questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium has a very high affinity for oxygen (ΔfG° for Al₂O₃ is very large and negative: −1582 kJ/mol). This makes it a powerful reducing agent capable of reducing metal oxides that carbon cannot reduce efficiently. In the thermite reaction (2Al + Fe₂O₃ → Al₂O₃ + 2Fe), Al displaces Fe because Al forms a more stable oxide. Similarly, Al reduces Cr₂O₃ to Cr and Mn₃O₄ to Mn (aluminothermic process).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Al's melting point (660°C) is not particularly low for metals. Al₂O₃ is extremely stable (not easily decomposed — it has m.p. 2072°C). Cost is not the primary reason. The key factor is aluminium's thermodynamic affinity for oxygen, which drives the highly exothermic oxide displacement reactions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a use of zeolites?

options.text: As a reducing agent in metallurgy
As a water softener by ion exchange (replacing Ca²⁺/Mg²⁺ with Na⁺)
As a fuel in internal combustion engines

questions.explanation_correct: Zeolites are used as water softeners through ion exchange. The sodium ions in the zeolite framework (NaZ) exchange with Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions in hard water: Na₂Z + Ca²⁺ → CaZ + 2Na⁺. The exhausted zeolite is regenerated by treatment with brine (NaCl solution). Zeolites are also used in laundry detergents as builders to soften water and as catalysts (e.g., ZSM-5) and molecular sieves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zeolites are not reducing agents, fuels, or pigments. They are aluminosilicate minerals with cage-like structures used primarily for ion exchange (water softening), catalysis (petrochemistry), and molecular sieving (gas separation and purification).

questions.question_text: When borax is heated strongly, the products formed are:

options.text: Sodium metaborate (NaBO₂) and boric anhydride (B₂O₃) as a transparent glassy bead

questions.explanation_correct: When borax (Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O) is heated: it first loses water and swells up, then fuses to form a clear transparent glassy bead. The bead consists of sodium metaborate and boric anhydride: Na₂B₄O₇ →(Δ) 2NaBO₂ + B₂O₃. This bead is used in the borax bead test for identifying metal ions — the B₂O₃ reacts with metal oxides to form coloured metaborates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaOH and B₂H₆ are not products of heating borax. Na₂CO₃ requires a carbon source. NaCl requires a chlorine source. The correct products are sodium metaborate (NaBO₂) and boric anhydride (B₂O₃), which together form the characteristic glassy borax bead.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following:
(i) CO₂ is a gas at room temperature; SiO₂ is a solid.
(ii) CO₂ is acidic; SiO₂ is also acidic.
(iii) CCl₄ is not hydrolysed by water; SiCl₄ is readily hydrolysed.
Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: All three statements are correct. (i) CO₂ is a gas (discrete molecule, weak intermolecular forces) while SiO₂ is a high-melting solid (3D covalent network). (ii) Both are acidic oxides: CO₂ + H₂O → H₂CO₃; SiO₂ + 2NaOH → Na₂SiO₃ + H₂O (SiO₂ reacts with bases but not water directly due to its network structure). (iii) CCl₄ is not hydrolysed because C has no vacant d-orbitals to accept lone pairs from water; SiCl₄ is readily hydrolysed (SiCl₄ + 2H₂O → SiO₂ + 4HCl) because Si has vacant 3d orbitals that accept lone pairs from water, facilitating the reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three statements are factually correct. CO₂ is indeed a gas while SiO₂ is a solid. Both are acidic oxides. CCl₄ resists hydrolysis (no d-orbitals on C) while SiCl₄ is readily hydrolysed (vacant d-orbitals on Si accept incoming nucleophile). Therefore, answer is (i), (ii), and (iii).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct order of increasing bond length in carbon-oxygen bonds?
questions.explanation_correct: The bond length increases as bond order decreases. CO has a triple bond (bond order 3, bond length 113 pm). CO₂ has double bonds (bond order 2, C=O bond length 116 pm). CO₃²⁻ has resonance-delocalised bonds with bond order 4/3 ≈ 1.33 (bond length ~129 pm). Therefore, the order of increasing bond length is: CO (113 pm) < CO₂ (116 pm) < CO₃²⁻ (129 pm), which corresponds to decreasing bond order: 3 > 2 > 1.33.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bond length is inversely proportional to bond order. CO has the highest bond order (3) and shortest bond. CO₃²⁻ has the lowest bond order (1.33) and longest bond. CO₂ is intermediate. The order CO < CO₂ < CO₃²⁻ for increasing bond length is correct.
